originalTitle: Mali lawmaker jailed in Ivory Coast for insulting president
title: A Story About Words and Rules in Africa!
content:
Hello, Little Explorers!

Hello, my little news friends! Today, we have an important story from our big, beautiful continent, Africa. It's a story about words and rules, and being kind to our neighbors. Sometimes, grown-ups can say things that get them into trouble, just like kids sometimes do. This story is about one such grown-up and what happened.

Meet Our Friends, Mali and Ivory Coast!

Africa is a very big place, full of many different countries. Today, our story takes us to two of these countries that are neighbors. Imagine your house and your friend's house next door – that's a bit like Mali and Ivory Coast. They share a border, which means they are very close to each other. Mali is a country that is mostly land, with lots of sand and interesting animals. It's famous for its ancient cities and rich history. Its capital city is called Bamako. Did you know that Mali has a big river called the Niger River? It's like a long, winding snake through the country! It helps many plants and animals grow. Next door is Ivory Coast. Ivory Coast has beautiful beaches and a lot of green forests. It's known for growing tasty things like cocoa beans, which are used to make chocolate! Yum! Its capital city is called Yamoussoukro, but many people also know Abidjan, which is a very big city there. It has tall buildings and busy markets. So, we have Mali, and we have Ivory Coast. Both are special places with their own people, languages, and cultures. They are like two friends living right next to each other, and it's always good for friends to get along!

Who Are the Grown-ups in Our Story?

In every country, there are leaders who help make sure things run smoothly. Think of your teacher in school, or your parents at home. Countries also have leaders to guide them. One of the grown-ups in our story is a man named Mamadou Hawa Gassama. He is from Mali. Mamadou Hawa Gassama is what we call a 'lawmaker.' What is a lawmaker? Well, imagine a big team of smart grown-ups who work together to create rules for the country. These rules are called 'laws.' Laws help everyone know what is right and wrong, and they keep everyone safe. So, Mamadou Hawa Gassama was part of this team in Mali, helping to make good rules for his country. He had an important job. Did you know that lawmakers help decide how schools are built, how hospitals work, and even how much food people can get? Their job is super important! The other grown-up in our story is the President of Ivory Coast. His name is Alassane Ouattara. The President is like the head leader of the whole country. He helps make sure the laws are followed and that the country is a good place for everyone to live. He is a very important person in Ivory Coast, like a captain of a big ship. So, we have a lawmaker from Mali and the President of Ivory Coast. Keep these two important people in mind for our story!

What Happened? Mean Words!

Now, let's talk about what happened. Sometimes, people say things that are not very nice. This is what happened with Mamadou Hawa Gassama, the lawmaker from Mali. He said some words about President Alassane Ouattara from Ivory Coast. What did he say? He used two strong words. He called President Ouattara a 'tyrant' and an 'enemy of Mali.' Wow! Those are very strong words, aren't they? Let's try to understand what these words mean. A 'tyrant' is like a ruler who is not fair and does not listen to anyone. Imagine someone who always wants their own way and doesn't care about others – that's a bit like what a tyrant would be. It's a word that usually means someone is being very unfair and mean. And an 'enemy of Mali'? That means someone who is against Mali, who doesn't want good things for Mali. It's like saying someone is a bad person for your country, someone who is against your team. So, Mamadou Hawa Gassama used these big, strong, and not-so-nice words to describe the President of Ivory Coast. He said them out loud, for many people to hear. This happened while he was in Ivory Coast, the President's own country! Did you know that words can be very powerful? They can make people happy, or they can make people sad. Sometimes, words can even cause big problems, especially when they are used to insult important leaders. We should always use our words carefully.

Why Are Words Important, and What Happened Next?

When Mamadou Hawa Gassama said those mean words, the people in Ivory Coast, especially the government, were not happy. Imagine if someone came to your house and said mean things about your parents – you wouldn't like that, would you? It's similar to that feeling. The government in Ivory Coast said that Mamadou Hawa Gassama's words were not okay. They felt he was insulting their president. Insulting means saying very disrespectful things that can hurt someone's feelings and reputation. It's like being very rude. Because he said these things, there were rules that needed to be followed. In Ivory Coast, it is against the law to insult the president, especially publicly. It's a bit like having a rule in school that says 'no bullying' or 'be kind to your friends' – there are consequences if you break them. So, what happened to Mamadou Hawa Gassama? He was put in jail in Ivory Coast. Jail is a place where grown-ups go when they break important rules or laws. He was told he would stay there for some time because of the mean words he used. This shows us that even grown-ups, especially leaders, need to be careful with their words. Just like we learn in school to use kind words and to think before we speak, it's a very important lesson for everyone. Words have power, and we must use them wisely. Did you know that different countries have different rules about what you can say? It's important to respect the rules of the place you are visiting, even if they are different from your home.

Being Good Neighbors

This story reminds us that Mali and Ivory Coast are neighbors. Just like you and your friends next door, countries need to get along and respect each other. When someone says mean things about a leader of another country, it can make things difficult between the two countries. It can make them less friendly. It's like when friends have a disagreement. It's always better to talk calmly and respectfully, rather than saying mean things that can hurt feelings and cause bigger problems. Talking is always better than fighting or saying hurtful things. Leaders of countries often talk to each other to solve problems and make sure everyone is happy and safe. This is called diplomacy. It's like grown-ups having a calm conversation to sort things out, making sure countries remain good friends. This whole situation makes us think about how important it is to be thoughtful with our words. Whether we are children or grown-ups, our words have power. We should always try to use them to build bridges, not walls, between people and between countries. So, remember this story from Africa. It teaches us that even strong leaders can get into trouble for their words, and that respect and kindness are important no matter where you are or who you are talking about. Let's all try to use our words wisely and make our world a happier, friendlier place!
summary: A lawmaker from Mali was jailed in Ivory Coast for using mean words to describe the President of Ivory Coast, showing that words have power and everyone must follow rules.
whyMatters: This story is important because it teaches us that words are powerful, and saying mean things about leaders, especially from other countries, can get grown-ups into big trouble. It also shows us that countries need to respect each other, just like friends need to be kind and polite to keep the peace.

originalTitle: South Africa and Israel expel each other's envoys in diplomatic row
title: South Africa and Israel expel each other's envoys in diplomatic row
content: South Africa accuses the Israeli envoy of insulting President Ramaphosa. Israel says the expulsion is "baseless".

originalTitle: Takeaways from the millions of newly released Epstein files
title: Big Boxes of Old Papers Tell Us Stories!
content:
Hello, my amazing friends across Africa! It's your kid-friendly news reporter here, ready to share something super interesting with you today. Imagine finding a very old treasure chest, not with gold, but with lots and lots of papers inside! That's a bit like what has happened. Many, many old papers have been opened up for people to look at.

What Are These Old Papers?

These are not just any old drawings or scribbles. These papers are like letters, notes, and records that grown-ups kept a long, long time ago. Think about your school notebook. It has your drawings and your writing, right? Well, these old papers are like giant notebooks for grown-ups who used to be very important. They have lots of writing on them, telling us about things that happened in the past. **Did you know?** In many parts of Africa, people used to pass down important stories and history by telling them to their children and grandchildren, not just by writing them down! It's called oral tradition.

Why Are These Papers Important?

These papers are very special because they help us learn about history. History is like a big storybook about everything that happened before we were born. When we look at old papers, it's like opening a window to the past. We can see what people were doing, what they were thinking, and who they were talking to. It helps us understand how things work now, and why certain rules are in place. **Did you know?** The oldest paper ever found was made from a plant called papyrus, a very long time ago in Africa!

Who Are The Important People In These Papers?

Many of these old papers mention important people. These are grown-ups who had big jobs. They might have been leaders in their community or even for a whole country. Imagine the person who helps decide things for your village or your town. These papers talk about people like that, but maybe even bigger! When we say "mention," it means their names are written down in the papers, like how your name is written on your school report. These papers talk about things these important people did, who they talked to, and where they went. **Did you know?** Even important leaders have to follow rules, just like you and me! Rules help everyone live together fairly and happily.

Emails and Secret Talks

Some of these papers are like old emails! Do you know what an email is? It's like sending a super-fast letter to someone using a computer or a phone. Even important people used to send emails to each other, talking about many things. These old emails are now part of the papers we can see. They show who was talking to whom, and what they were discussing. It's like finding old message notes between your parents and their friends. One of the papers even has emails between a very important leader and another important person, sometimes called 'The Duke' in some stories. They talked about different things, and now we can read their messages. It helps us understand how they worked and what was happening a long time ago. **Did you know?** The first email was sent even before many of your parents were born! It was a very big invention.

Why Do We Open Old Papers Now?

Sometimes, governments or big groups decide it's time for everyone to know what happened in the past. It's like when your teacher shows you old photos from your school's history. Opening these papers means that everyone can learn from them. It helps us make sure that important people always follow the rules and do things in a fair way. It reminds everyone that honesty and doing the right thing are very important, no matter how big or small your job is. When we learn from the past, we can help make the future even better for everyone, especially for children like you. So, remember, even old papers can tell us amazing stories and teach us valuable lessons! **Did you know?** In some African cultures, elders are highly respected because they hold the wisdom and history of the community, just like these old papers hold past stories! It's all about learning, growing, and making sure our world is a fair and happy place for everyone. That's all for today from your friendly news reporter!
summary: Many old and important papers, including emails, have been opened for everyone to see, helping us learn about history and the actions of important leaders from a long time ago.
whyMatters: This is important because these old papers help us understand what happened in the past, teach us about important people, and remind everyone that following rules and being fair is important for a happy world.
